titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kings County Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers publications ARC.146
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-28T10:06-0500

did.unittitle: Kings County Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers publications

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: New York State Society of Professional Engineers. Kings County Chapter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Kings County Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers publications date from 1940 to 1966 and measure 0.2 linear feet. Runs of three publications are included in the collection: The Engineer's Bulletin, The Kings County Professional Engineers' Bulletin, and Kings County Professional Engineer. Publications include reports from chapter committees, meeting minutes, brief articles relevant to area engineers, and abstracts of lectures delivered at chapter meetings. Publications also list members of the executive board, committee members, and new members to the chapter.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The New York State Society of Professional Engineers was the founding state society of the National Society of Professional Engineers. The Bronx County Chapter, New York State's first chapter, was founded in 1926, followed by the Kings County Chapter in 1928. The Society's mission was to provide engineers with professional development and economic opportunities. The Kings County Chapter held regular monthly meetings at the Brooklyn Engineers' Club, located on Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights. During the time period covered in this collection, membership grew steadily, from 1600 members in 1949 to 2200 members in the late 1950s.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Kings County Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers publications, ARC.146, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition for the collection are unknown.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Publications of the Brooklyn Engineers' Club are also available at the Brooklyn Historical Society; see ARC.156.
